tossups.question: Artifacts found near this river often depict unicorns, tigers, or rhinoceroses and were written in an unknown script studied by Asko Parpola. Near the north end of this river, the trading colony of Shortugai provided access to lapis lazuli mines. John Marshall led early excavations of cities on this river, and later excavations were overseen by Mortimer Wheeler. Mound F of a city on this river contains the so-called “Great Granary.” The earliest known (*) flush toilets and remarkable drainage systems were found in cities on this river. Cities on this river connected to the sea through ports like Meluhha and Lothal. The “Dancing Girl” sculpture was found in a city on this river that is also home to the “Great Bath.” Soapstone stamp seals were found in cities like Mohenjo Daro on this river. For 10 points, name this river whose valley names the Harappan civilization of India.

The Megabyxus ran a cult to this deity at Ephesus, whose statues appear to have multiple rows of breasts that probably represent bull testicles or gourds. As a child, this deity pulled out Brontes’ chest hair, making him appear to have mange. This deity saved Iakhos from his mother Aura, who became an insane killer as a result of insulting this deity. This deity killed the Aloadai (*) giants by running between them, causing them to accidentally shoot one another. This deity was worshipped in a festival where young girls dressed as bears. After Oeneus failed to worship this goddess of childbirth, she sent him a beast which was killed by Atalanta and Meleager, the Calydonian Boar. Born on the floating island of Delos, this goddess turned Actaeon into a deer after he saw her bathing. For 10 points, name this Greek goddess of the moon and the hunt.

This poet described “the town … frozen solid in a vice” and wrote that the night has no knowledge of the coming dawn in a work dedicated to an exiled friend. A poem by this author addresses an “ancient interrogator of the moon” and says that she has always been afraid of mummers before claiming that “gravestones are fragile … Absurd!” In that poem, this writer asks “what have poets … to do with sin?” and requests “the peace of the tomb.” This poet described “something like a smile” on the face of a woman waiting in line who asked her “Can you describe this?” in her (*) “Instead of a Preface,” which opens a poem that states “I have a lot of work to do today; I need to slaughter memory” and contains a “Crucifixion” section beginning “Weep not for me, mother,” about her son imprisoned for 17 months. For 10 points, name this Russian Acmeist poet of “Poem without a Hero” and “Requiem.”

A correction to this equation scales one variable as the normalized temperature to the 0.38 power; that correction relaxes the assumption that one quantity in this equation is temperature-independent and that correction is named for Watson. The August-Roche-Magnus formula is used to correct this formula when the saturation vapor pressure is temperature dependent. This equation is derived by noting that the chemical potential is equal across a (*) phase boundary, then applying the Gibbs-Duhem relation. In one form, this equation is stated as the derivative of pressure with respect to temperature equals latent heat over temperature times change in specific volume. For 10 points, name this doubly eponymous equation used to find the slope of coexistence curves.

Description acceptable. Time inconsistency models characterize how this process is conducted by an individual at different points in time. In Herbert Simon’s book on this process’s “administrative” type, people will employ the satisficing strategy during this process. It’s not (*) thinking, but heuristics dictate a majority of this process in a book that examines the System 1 and System 2 modes that conduct this process. The 2017 Nobel Prize in Economics was given to Richard Thaler for research into “nudges,” which tweak rationality assumptions and thereby change this process itself; Thaler opposes the homo economicus characterization of this process. Preference relations dictate this process’s outcome. For 10 points, name this process that lends its name to fields of economics studying people’s systematic actions among a set of alternatives.
tossups.answer: behavior [accept decision-making or choosing or clear equivalents; accept behavioral economics or decision theory or any type of choice theory like rational choice theory, social choice theory, etc.]

tossups.question: In one of these locations, a man breathes on a window and draws a heart with an arrow and the name “Anna” on it. In another of these places, two men and a woman start singing “The Band Played On,” before a man who earlier popped a boy’s balloon with a cigarette picks up the tune. That man later tries to drop a silver cigarette lighter with crossed tennis rackets in one of these places. A speech given in one of these locations says that “In (*) Switzerland...they had five hundred years of democracy and peace - and what did that produce? The cuckoo clock.” Bruno Anthony kills Miriam in one of these places in Strangers on a Train, where he fights with Guy Haines on a structure which spins out of control. For 10 points, name this type of location in which Holly Martins and Harry Lime talk in The Third Man in a scene featuring the Wiener Riesenrad Ferris Wheel.
tossups.answer: amusement park [accept fair, fun park, any other synonyms; be nice and antiprompt on “merry-go-round” or “ferris wheel,” most clues apply to one or the other; accept ferris wheel before second sentence]

tossups.question: This non-infectious disease is one of the few contraindications for the ParaGard IUD. A protein whose levels are used to diagnose this disease has the GAIT element in its 3’ UTR (3 prime). T2 hyperintensities on brain MRI cause the “double panda sign” in sufferers of this disease. Trientine can be used to treat this disease in patients whose bone marrow is suppressed by the most common drug used to treat it. This disease, which can be diagnosed by low (*) ceruloplasmin levels, is usually treated by D-Penicillamine. A classic sign of this disease is caused by deposits on Descemet’s membrane that are visible under slit-lamp exam, called Kayser-Fleischer rings. For 10 points, it’s my last Penn Bowl, so stop writing on this genetic disease caused by mutation of the ATP7B gene that causes buildup of copper.

A character from this film quips, “Truth is like poetry. And most people fucking hate poetry.” The opening scene of this film features a quotation from Mark Twain that says “It ain’t what you don’t know that gets you into trouble. It’s what you know for sure that just ain’t so.” This movie describes Lewis Ranieri as a man who (*) “changed your life more than Michael Jordan, the iPod, and YouTube put together.” This film’s title refers to the practice of betting on the value of a good depreciating. Cameos in this film include Selena Gomez in a casino and Margot (Mar-go) Robbie in a bubble bath. This movie was based off of a book subtitled “Inside the Doomsday Machine” which was written by Michael Lewis. For 10 points, name this film about the 2008 collapse of the U.S. housing market, starring Ryan Gosling, Steve Carell, and Christian Bale.

Kenneth Pomeranz pointed to the availability of this good in the West to explain the “Great Divergence.” After an incident at Silkstone, the 7th Earl of Shaftesbury reformed labor requirements for working with this good, preventing the employment of girls as hurriers and trappers. The Bridgewater Canal was built for the transport of this good from Worsley. A region nicknamed for the use of this good included the boroughs of Wolverhampton and Dudley in the West (*) Midlands. Working with this good became safer with the invention of a new lamp by Sir Humphry Davy. It’s not a metal, but the Newcomen engine was first used to facilitate the extraction of this good. A form of this good used to do better iron smelting was known as coke. For 10 points, name this black fuel that helped ignite the Industrial Revolution in Britain.

Two characters in this novel are described as “throw-away people, two lawless outlaws” while swaddling a baby on the banks of a river. This novel states, “It was not a story to pass on” to explain why people forgot its title character. A man in this novel loves his “Thirty-Mile Woman” because she gathered up his “jumbled-up pieces” and gave them back to him. Another character in this novel follows a trail of blossoming flowers after escaping from a (*) chain gang. After the protagonist of this novel despairs that her “best thing” has left her, her lover tells her, “You your best thing.” The protagonist of this novel attacks Mr. Bodwin, mistaking him for the abusive schoolteacher whom she had run away from after a brutal whipping. For 10 points, name this novel in which Sethe is haunted by the title daughter she killed to keep out of slavery, by Toni Morrison.

A port on this body of water once called Akhtiar was founded by Admiral Thomas MacKenzie. The ship Taif (tah-eef), bearing Adolphus Slade, was the only survivor of a battle in this body of water. Although not Greek, that battle here was the last major battle between sailing ship fleets due to the use of explosive shells. To confine a major fleet to this body of water, the Great Powers signed the 1841 London Convention. To defend one of its ports, Eduard Totleben ordered a fleet sunk to block the harbor, and the subsequent (*) siege ended after the taking of Malakoff Redoubt. The decisive battle of Sinope (sai-noh-pee) on this body of water was won by Admiral Nakhimov. Grigory Potemkin fortified the port of Sevastopol on this body of water. For 10 points, name this body of water which was the center of naval competition between Russia and the Ottoman Empire.
tossups.answer: Black Sea [Chernoye More; Chorne More; Karadeniz]

tossups.question: This work uses a somewhat belabored simile contrasting an adulteress with a woman who remarries after her husband’s death to argue that its addressees have died to the law and are released from it. This work’s speaker then laments that knowledge of the law produces the desire to act against it, saying he is a “slave to the law of sin.” This letter warns addressees against taking revenge because “Vengeance is mine; I shall repay, says the Lord.” It claims that (*) circumcision does not matter, since it becomes invalid for someone who breaks the law. This letter warns that “the wages of sin is death” and that “the righteous shall live by faith,” inspiring Martin Luther’s doctrine of faith over works. For 10 points, name this first and longest epistle by Paul, addressed to the inhabitants of an empire’s capital.
tossups.answer: Epistle to the Romans [or Letter to the Romans]

tossups.question: Miranda Fricker argues that one of these things centers around reception of testimony, and illustrates the lack of this concept with the story of Marge and Herbert Greenleaf from The Talented Mr. Ripley. Linda Zagzebski argues that both coherentist and foundationalist theories of knowledge are susceptible to “gettierology,” (get-ee-eye-ology) instead supporting a theory of this type called “Reliabilism” that came out of (*) Ernest Sosa’s “The Raft and the Pyramid.” Martha Nussbaum compared a sophisticated agent adept in these things to a talented jazz improvisationist, and defended this type of ethical theory against charges of relativism. Ethical theories that center around these things are distinct from both consequentialist or deontological theories and often aim to promote “flourishing.” For 10 points, name these beneficial character qualities that name a type of ethics created by Aristotle.
tossups.answer: virtues [accept “vices” until “lack of”; accept “virtue epistemology” until “Martha Nussbaum”; prompt on specific virtues like “justice”]

tossups.question: A young Robert Heinlein assisted this activist in a 1934 political movement aimed at introducing a public works program and a progressive income tax. This person coined the phrase “white collar” in a 1919 book attacking yellow journalists like William Randolph Hearst, who later spearheaded negative press coverage of this activist’s EPIC (E-P-I-C) campaign. This person wrote a book subtitled How I Got Licked after losing the 1934 (*) California gubernatorial election to Frank Merriam, who won by reminding voters of this man’s previous membership in the Socialist Party. This author of The Brass Check remarked “I was aiming for the public’s heart, and by accident I hit it in the stomach” after his novel about Lithuanian immigrants in Chicago led Congress to pass the Pure Food and Drug Act. For 10 points, name this muckraker who wrote The Jungle.

Hinton and Zemel (zeh-mahl) used a function based on this quantity to compute recognition weights used to train an autoencoder. Two-sided estimation is used by the Bennett’s acceptance ratio method to approximate this quantity. One relation states that this function for a liquid system is bounded above by a reference plus the difference between the Hamiltonians of the true and reference systems; that is the Bogoliubov (buh-GOAL-you-bahv) inequality. This quantity is minimized when a system is touching a thermal reservoir, and it is equal to (*) negative Boltzmann’s constant times temperature times the natural log of the partition function. This state function is the maximum amount of work obtainable from a reversible process and can be expressed as internal energy minus entropy times temperature. For 10 points, name this non-Gibbs free energy.
tossups.answer: Helmholtz free energy [prompt on partial answers like free energy or energy]

tossups.question: Robert Longo created a sculpted black version of this object slanting into the ground like a sinking ship. This object shown in “Untitled (The Pequod)” is embossed with questions like “Who dies first? Who laughs last?” in a Barbara Kruger work. One work hides this object in a landscape, its image formed out of a tree, stars, and clouds during a sunset. That painting is by Frederic Church and is named this object “in the Sky.” A group of people in black stand under many of these objects in “Avenue in the Rain” by Childe Hassam. (*) Encaustic paint over newspaper was used to create a “white” version of this object, and this object was painted in three smaller versions stacked on top of each other. For 10 points, name this subject of Jasper Johns paintings, which show different versions of the American one.

Fourth movement of Janacek’s Sinfonietta (sin-fone-yet-a) begins with these instruments playing a repetitive motif of (read slowly) four A-flats-B-flat-A-flat-G. These instruments are paired a major second interval apart in the “Game of Pairs” section of Bartok’s Concerto for Orchestra. The final movement of Hindemith’s sonata for this instrument and piano borrows a theme from the chorale “All Men Must Die.” Jean-Baptiste Arban (*) published the most famous pedagogical method used for teaching this instrument. Maurice Andre popularized the use of “piccolo” variant of this instrument in Baroque works such as Brandenburg Concerto No. 2 instead of the usual “natural” variant in order to play in clarino register. For 10 points, name this high pitched brass instrument.

In one essay, this man discussed a criticism he received that began with “Three cheers for mere Anarchy!” and suggested changing the nationalities of names in Roth or Updike novels. In another essay, this author condensed a work’s meaning to “the thought of their humanity - like yours… Ugly” and described receiving a letter from a young boy who did not know that Yonkers had tribal customs. This author wrote about Nancy and Michael attempting to get rid of local religion by fencing off the title (*) “Dead Men’s Path” in one story. Jonathan runs a bicycle taxi service and remains optimistic after a robbery because "nothing puzzles God" in this author's story “Civil Peace.” This author of “Colonialist Criticism” called Joseph Conrad a "thoroughgoing racist” in “An Image of Africa.” For 10 points, name this author who wrote about Okonkwo in Things Fall Apart.

One stochastic method for solving problems of this type adaptively estimates lower order moments, and is the Adam algorithm. One algorithm for solving these problems updates by setting the n plus first point equal to the nth point minus a constant times the gradient at the nth point. A naive algorithm for solving these problems involves repeatedly incrementing away from an arbitrary point, and seeing if the (*) objective increases. Other algorithms for solving these problems include gradient descent and hill climb algorithms. Linear programming problems are a type of this problem which can be solved by the simplex method. For 10 points, name these problems of finding the largest or smallest values obtained by functions.

Harold Bloom claimed that this character dies not as a Christian martyr but as a victim to the “religion of Moloch.” This character’s mother had a maid named Barbara whose lover “prov’d mad,” and who taught this character a song about a poor soul who “sat sighing by a sycamore tree” whose “salt tears fell from her, and soften’d the stones,” the (*) “willow song”. Her name comes from the Greek for “unfortunate,” and she is described by her husband as an “ill-starred wench.” This character’s father is told that “an old black ram” is tupping his “white ewe,” which represents this character. This woman’s strawberry-embroidered handkerchief is used to convince her husband that she is being unfaithful, which causes him to smother her. For 10 points, name this woman whom Iago accuses of having an affair with Cassio and is the wife of Othello.

bonuses.leadin: The target sequences in this technique lies next to the NGG protospascer adjacent motif. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: CRISPR [or Clustered Regularly Interspaced Short Palindromic Repeats]
parts: Name this gene editing system which uses the Cas9 nuclease to make specific cuts in a target sequence by finding regions complementary to a guide RNA.

A 4-HT inducible version of the CRISPR system makes use of one of these short protein sequences stuck into the middle of Cas9. Analogous to introns, these peptides can excise themselves from proteins.
This Berkeley professor and co-author of the memoir A Crack in Creation is one of the co-creators of CRISPR. She also crystallized the Tetrahymena Group I ribozyme while at Yale.

bonuses.leadin: A proponent of this type of warfare arranged for the SMS Ostfriesland to be sunk off the coast of Virginia in a public demonstration. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: air warfare [or the air force; accept any descriptive answer that suggests the military use of aircraft, such as but not limited to air power; winged defense etc.]
parts: Identify this kind of warfare which was advocated for in the US by Billy Mitchell, who was eventually court martialled for insubordination. Mitchell’s protege “Hap” Arnold was also expert on this type of warfare. Description acceptable.
Mitchell’s argument that battleships were susceptible to air attack was ironically proved correct when the Japanese attacked this Hawaiian naval base on December 7, 1941.

This most successful American fighter ace during World War One, was a character witness in Billy Mitchell’s court martial. This CEO of Eastern Air Lines visited Russia during World War Two to study the Soviet air force.

bonuses.leadin: This philosopher developed a thought experiment involving the “original position.” For 10 points each,
answers_sanitized: T. M. Scanlon [or Thomas Michael Scanlon or Tim Scanlon]
communitarianism [prompt on “universalism”; do not accept or prompt on “communism”]
parts: Name this philosopher who argued for “justice as fairness,” and whose “difference principle” claimed that society should try to benefit those people who are worst off.

This Harvard philosopher and former student of Rawls criticizes aspects of the original position and the “veil of ignorance” it requires. He laid out his theory of contractualism in the book What We Owe To Each Other.

This other critique of Rawls ascribed to Michael Sandel and Alasdair MacIntyre points out the difficulty of universalizing from one “Archimedean point.” It calls for a non-individualistic, non-abstract view of the self.

bonuses.leadin: A documentary of this author’s life “in four chapters” intertwines moments of his life with snippets of his novels and culminates in his attempted coup and public suicide. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: they all have three moles [prompt on “birthmarks” or whatnot]
parts: Name this author of The Temple of the Golden Pavilion and The Sea of Fertility tetralogy.

This first novel of the Sea of Fertility series shows the relationship between Satoko Ayakura and Kiyoaki Matsugae, who keeps a journal of prophetic dreams, which he gives to Shigekuni Honda on his death.

Kiyoaki is reincarnated as Isao Iinuma in Runaway Horses, Ying Chan in The Temple of Dawn, and the teenager Toru Yasunaga in The Decay of the Angel; Honda recognizes each figure as a reincarnation of Kiyoaki by this sign.

bonuses.leadin: Charles Jackson was the first to propose the quinoid structure of this intermediate. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this negatively-charged intermediate seen during nucleophilic aromatic substitution. Formation of this intermediate is the rate-limiting step during the substitution reaction.

Negative charges on Meisenheimer intermediates can be stabilized by electron-withdrawing groups, such as nitro groups, thanks to this effect, where electron density is pulled through sigma-bond networks.
Due to its high electronegativity, this most electronegative halogen is the best leaving group for nucleophilic aromatic substitution.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about some sources on Late Antiquity. For 10 points each:
parts: This 3rd Century Bishop of Carthage wrote about a plague which may have had similarities to Ebola. That plague named for him killed Claudius Gothicus and coincided with Trajan Decius’ persecution of Christians.

Sidonius Apollinaris remarked in letters on the weighty conversations at this ruler’s banquets. He replaced the philosopher Boethius with the historian Cassiodorus as his chief minister, and legends call him Dietrich von Bern.
The diplomat Priscus is a key source on this ruler, travelling to his camp while part of an embassy. This Hunnic leader was defeated by Aetius at the Battle of Chalons.

bonuses.leadin: This piece calls for a wind machine and thunder sheets to depict a storm in the section titled “The Descent.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this tone poem depicting the titular mountain range. Four trombones play similar ascending chords as the opening of the composer’s Also Sprach Zarathustra in this piece’s “Peak” motif.

This enigmatic unfinished piece by Scriabin (skree-a-bin) was originally meant to be played by an orchestra and a chorus during a week-long ascent of the Himalayas. Alexander Nemtin transcribed the prelude to this piece entitled “Prefatory Action.”
This composer depicted the love serenade of a mountaineer in a slow English horn melody doing a call and response with an oboe in the third movement of Harold in Italy.

bonuses.leadin: An artist known for painting these objects promised to have sex with Richard Nixon if he would stop the Vietnam War. For 10 points each:
parts: Yayoi Kusama often paints enormous numbers of these things in many forms, inspired by her hallucinations. She describes them as “a way to infinity.”

This other contemporary Japanese artist started the “superflat” movement, blurring “high” and “low” culture. He paints scary-looking teddy bears which have been seen on Louis Vuitton bags and Kanye West albums.
This somewhat less contemporary Japanese artist created woodblock prints showing Thirty-six Views of Mount Fuji, including one in which it is overshadowed by a large wave.

bonuses.leadin: A Mark Twain discussion of the “decay of the art of” this practice calls it “the fourth Grace, the tenth Muse, man’s best and surest friend.” For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: lying [accept “The Decay of the Art of Lying” or “The Art of Lying”; accept word forms and synonyms like prevaricating or fibbing; prompt on anything related to “not telling the truth”]
parts: Name this practice, “the art of” which is also discussed in a dialogue in which Vivan argues to Cyril that Art is superior to Life.
“The Art of Lying” was written by this author. This epigrammatic author created Lord Darlington, who claims “I can resist everything except temptation,” in his play Lady Windermere’s Fan.
This Catholic author wrote about Matilda, who burned to death because she told lies, in his satire of didactic stories, Cautionary Tales for Children.

bonuses.leadin: In one opera by this man, the title character is elected May King because there are no virgins in town to be the May Queen. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this composer of Albert Herring and The Turn of the Screw, who also wrote A Young Person’s Guide to the Orchestra.
In this most famous Benjamin Britten opera, the title character is a small-town sailor who is thrown into disgrace and commits suicide after two of his apprentices die at sea.

This is the second part of Britten’s Let’s Make an Opera! series for children, framed by a story of children writing their own opera. In it, the rich Crome children smuggle the title character in a trunk to freedom.

bonuses.leadin: George Miller famously wrote that this could store seven items, plus or minus two. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this process, which is often divided into short-term and long-term versions.
This type of memory is contrasted with procedural memory; it can be divided into semantic memory, the recall of facts, and episodic memory, the recall of events in one’s past.

Baddeley and Hitch divided short-term memory into the central executive, the visuospatial sketchpad, the episodic buffer, and this structure that stores audio information. It has a short-term store and an articulatory loop.

bonuses.leadin: In the middle of her floor routine, this gymnast winked at Sean Johnson in the audience. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this gymnast, who won a record-setting five gold medals for team, all-around, floor, vault, and beam at the 2016 Rio Olympics along with teammates Aly Raisman and Gabby Douglas.
Simone Biles is one of the few women to win five medals in a single Olympics, along with this Romanian gymnast, the first gymnast to score a perfect 10 for her routine on the uneven bars.
Simone Biles won the Rio vault event by performing this difficult move, consisting of a back handspring, two-and-a-half twists in the air, and a blind landing.

bonuses.leadin: Quantum fields whose quanta are these particles obey canonical commutation relations. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these particles. Wave functions of systems of identical kinds of these integer-spin particles are symmetric under exchange according to the spin-statistics theorem.
The W and Z bosons mediate the weak interaction and are thus called this type of boson. These bosons have a spin of 1.

In QFT, performing this process is often necessary to ensure that a product of field operators is well-defined. Performing this procedure places all creation operators to the left of all annihilation operators in the product.

bonuses.leadin: A pile of comic books provides the only “note of color” in the title location of this poem. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: losing [prompt on synonyms or alternate forms]
parts: Name this poem that opens “Oh, but it is dirty!” and speculates about the people who live in the title place, closing with the assertion, “Somebody loves us all.”
“Filling Station” is by this author of “One Art,” who wrote “The Armadillo” for her friend Robert Lowell.
A repeated line in “One Art” states that the art of this action isn’t hard to master, and advises the addressee to practice this skill “farther” and “faster.”

bonuses.leadin: A medieval chronicler of this name from Corvey Abbey wrote about Otto the Great in his work Res Gestae Saxoniae. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Widukind of Corvey [or Widuking King of the Saxons; Wittekind]
Holy Roman Empire [or Heiliges Römisches Reich Deutscher Nation; do NOT accept or prompt on “Roman Empire”]
Henry the Fowler [Heinrich der Finkler; Heinrich der Vogler; prompt on partial answer]
parts: Give this name that was also held by a ruler who led a rebellion after the destruction of the sacred Irminsul pillar. The forces of that ruler of this name were victims of the Verden Massacre.
Otto the Great ruled over this political entity made up of a hodgepodge of mainly German principalities after being crowned by Pope John XII in 962 CE. This state’s first leader was Charlemagne.
This Duke of Saxony was father of Otto the Great. This man allegedly gained his epithet after he received word that he was crowned king while he was mending his bird nets.

bonuses.leadin: These people got revenge for their older half-brothers placing them on an anthill by turning them into monkeys. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: headbands [prompt on “headgear” or items that might look similar like “bandanas” or “hats” or “crowns”]
parts: Name these brothers, Hunahpu (wah-nuh-pwuh) and Xbalanque (sheh-bay-lan-kay), who defeated the lords of the underworld Xibalba (she-ball-bah) in a ball-game.
The Hero Twins shot out this god’s jeweled set of false teeth with a blowgun and replaced them with corn, causing him to die of shame. They also defeated his sons Zipacna and Cabrakan.

In Mayan art, this article of clothing is used to identify the Hero Twins and their close relatives. In The Maya Scribe and His World, Michael Coe nicknamed the Hero Twins after this item of clothing.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer some things about Cardinal John Newman.
parts: John Newman may be best known for writing this autobiographical defense in response to Charles Kingsley where he defended his conversion to Catholicism following the publication of Tract 90.

Newman justified his departure from this religion in Apologia Pro Vita Sua. Newman’s writings influenced the followers of the Oxford movement, who called for the return of certain older Christian traditions in this church.
Following his conversion, Newman was appointed as a cardinal by this intellectual pope. This “Rosary Pope” notably addressed the rights and conditions of the working class in Rerum Novarum.

bonuses.leadin: The political parties of this country aligned in the Punto Fijo pact, leading to domination by the Accion Democratica and Social Christian parties. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Alo Presidente [or Hello, Mr. President; Hello, President; or similar translations]
parts: Name this country where the leader of a coup against Carlos Andres Perez declared that he had failed “for now.” This country faced 1989 riots in its capital due to the implementation of IMF-proposed reforms.

This man led the aforementioned coup against Carlos Andres Perez. This Venezuelan President sought to create a socialist “Bolivarian Revolution” until he was killed by lung cancer and succeeded by Nicolas Maduro.
Chavez used this weekly, unscripted TV show to maintain popularity, doing fun things like expropriating buildings live. In a 2006 episode of this show, Chavez nicknamed George W. Bush “Mr. Danger”.

bonuses.leadin: Associating groups with topological spaces can be really useful. For 10 points each:
parts: One such group is the fundamental group, which for the circle is this group.
The fundamental group is useful because it is invariant under maps of this type. These are continuous maps between topological spaces with continuous inverses.

Another kind of a group useful in topology is the cohomology group, the first of which is obtained by dividing the fundamental group by its commutator subgroup. This means that the order of multiplication in the cohomology group does not matter, making it this kind of group.

bonuses.leadin: The title character of this book claimed that he cut off his finger because it got in the way of his pottery wheel. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this novel, in which the narrator is inspired by the title character’s love of life to sleep with a widow who is consequently beheaded. The two start a lignite mine together while staying at the hotel of Madame Hortense.
This author of Zorba the Greek also wrote The Last Temptation of Christ and The Odyssey: A Modern Sequel.
This other Greek novelist of The Boundless Garden and The Gypsy Girl wrote about an old woman, Hadoula, who kills young girls to spare them a woman’s hard life in The Murderess.
